questions.question:
Question 1: A patient with right flank pain and fever has renal angle tenderness on examination. Which of 
the following forms the boundaries of this angle?

options.a: Lower border of 11th rib and medial border of erector spinae
options.b: Lower border of 12th rib and medial border of erector spinae
options.c: Lower border of 11th rib and lateral border of erector spinae
options.d: Lower border of 12th rib and lateral border of erector spinae

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and the renal angle tenderness are suggestive of acute pyelonephritis. 
The renal angle is formed by the lower border of the 12th rib and the lateral border of the erector 
spinae. 950 
Sold by @itachibot The lower pole of the kidney occupies this angle. Tenderness in this angle is usually suggestive of 
infection in and around the kidney or renal stones.

questions.question: Question 2: Identify the angle shown in the image below.
questions.explanation:
The angle shown in the image is the costovertebral angle, formed between the lower border of the 
12th rib and the vertebral column. Causes for pain/tenderness at the costovertebral angle include: • Nephrolithiasis • Pelviureteric junction obstruction • Pyelonephritis • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) - caused by Hantavirus. 951 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: 940 
Sold by @itachibot Arrange the coverings of the kidney from within outwards:
questions.explanation:
The 4 coverings of the kidney from within outwards are as follows: • True or fibrous capsule - formed by the collagen-rich connective tissue. • Perinephric fat or adipose capsule - consists of fat and occupies the space between the fibrous 
capsule and the renal fascia. • Renal fascia • Paranephric fat - occupies the space between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the 
thoracolumbar fascia.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following fascia attaches the perirenal fascia to the peritoneum?
questions.explanation:
The lateroconal fascia attaches the perirenal fascia to the peritoneum. It extends from the lateral 
margin of perirenal fascia and attaches to the parietal peritoneum. Option A: Gerota's fascia is the perirenal fascia. The kidney and the suprarenal gland are enclosed 
within anterior and posterior lamina of the perirenal fascia. The anterior lamina of the perirenal 
fascia blends with the connective tissue surrounding the great vessels behind the duodenum and 
pancreas. The posterior lamina continues as the lateroconal fascia. Option C: Thoracolumbar fascia is a complex arrangement of multiple fascial layers in the 
thoracolumbar region. This fascia encloses the paraspinal muscles, quadratus lumborum muscle 
and the lattisimus dorsi muscle. Option D: Treitz's fascia has been used to refer to the fusion fascia behind the head of pancreas. 952 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:

structure?
questions.explanation:
The marked structure in the image is the right kidney. The pylorus of the stomach is not related to 
the anterior surface of the right kidney. The anterior relations of the right kidney: The below image shows the cross-section of the abdomen at the level of kidney. Intraperitone

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following areas of the left kidney is separated from its relation by a peritoneal 
layer?
questions.explanation:
The anterior surface of the left kidney in relation with the jejunal loops (marked as 2) is separated 
from the structure by a peritoneal layer. As the kidneys are located retroperitoneally, intraperitoneal anterior relations are separated from 
it by a peritoneal layer. The anterior relations of the left kidney include: Intraperitone

questions.question:
Question 7: Which of the following is related to the marked area in the image? 942 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked area in the image of the left kidney is related to the stomach. The anterior relations of the right kidney: The anterior relations of the left kidney: The posterior relations of the kidneys: • One vessel - subcostal vessels • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis. 955 
Sold by @itachibot • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs Intraperitone

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following areas of the anterior surface of the right kidney is separated by a layer 
of peritoneum?
questions.explanation:
The anterior surface of the right kidney related to the right lobe of the liver (marked as 1) is 
separated by a layer of peritoneum. As the kidneys are located retroperitoneally, intraperitoneal anterior relations are separated from 
it by a peritoneal layer. The anterior relations of the right kidney: Intraperitone 
al Right lobe of liverSmall intes 
tine Retroperitone 
al Right suprarenal gland2ndpa 
rt of duoednumHepatic flexu 
re of colon 957 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following is not a posterior relation of the marked structure?
questions.explanation:
The marked structure in the given image is the left kidney. The sympathetic chain is not a 
posterior relation of the left kidney. The posterior relations of the kidneys are as follows: • One vessel - subcostal vessels • Two ligaments - medial and lateral arcuate ligaments • Three nerves - subcostal, iliohypogastric, and ilioinguinal nerves • Four muscles - diaphragm, psoas major, quadratus lumborum, and transverse abdominis. • The right kidney is related to the 12th rib and the left kidney is related to the 11th and 12th ribs The below image shows the cross section of the abdomen at the level of kidney. 958 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 10: What is the correct arrangement of the structures in the marked area from anterior to 
posterior? 944 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Renal artery, renal vein, renal pelvis
options.b: Renal vein, renal artery, renal pelvis
options.c: Renal pelvis, renal artery, renal vein
options.d: Renal vein, renal pelvis, renal artery

questions.explanation:
The marked area is the hilum of the kidney. It contains the following structures from anterior to 
posterior: • Renal vein • Renal artery • Renal pelvis

questions.question: Question 11: What is the structure into which the renal papillae open?
questions.explanation:
959 
Sold by @itachibot The renal papillae open into the minor calyces. The papilla is the conical apex of a renal pyramid, where the urine from the collecting ducts enters 
into the minor calyces. The minor calyces unite to form the major calyces, which further unite to 
form the renal pelvis. The kidney is divided into an outer cortex and an inner medulla. The renal medulla contains 
many striated and conical pyramids. The base of the pyramid is peripherally located, whereas the 
apex is directed towards the renal sinus (hilum). The renal cortex is subcapsular and arches over 
the bases of the pyramids. It extends between the pyramids towards the renal sinus as renal 
columns.

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following contributes to the nerve supply of the kidney?
questions.explanation:
The coeliac plexus contributes to the nerve supply of the kidneys. Nerve supply of the kidney: • Coeliac ganglion and plexus • Aorticorenal ganglion • Lowest thoracic splanchnic nerve • First lumbar splanchnic nerve • Aortic plexus The rami from these structures form a dense network of autonomic plexus around the renal artery 
called the renal plexus. They control the blood flow between the cortex and medulla. 960 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 13: A 20-year-old man presented with left flank pain, varicocele, hematuria, and headache. On 
examination, BP was 170/100 mm Hg. CT abdomen was done and a diagnosis of Nutcracker 
syndrome was made. What is the cause?

options.a: Compression of left renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
options.b: Compression of left renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein
options.c: Compression of right renal vein between abdominal aorta and superior mesenteric artery
options.d: Compression of right renal vein between inferior vena cava and superior mesenteric vein

questions.explanation:
The most likely cause is compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and 
superior mesenteric artery. This manifests as nutcracker syndrome. Nutcracker syndrome is characterized by left renal vein hypertension, which occurs due to the 
compression of the left renal vein between the abdominal aorta and the superior mesenteric 
artery. This is because the left renal vein is posterior and inferior to the superior mesenteric 
artery. The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein. It runs anterior to the aorta just below the 
origin of the superior mesenteric artery and drains into the inferior vena cava after crossing the 
midline. Note: The left kidney is preferred in donor nephrectomy than the right because of the long course 
of the left renal vein. 961 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: A 56-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with severe pain in the left 
flank region. CT-examination revealed occlusion of the left renal vein. The condition would 
impede the blood flow through all of the following veins except:
questions.explanation:
The left subcostal vein does not drain into the left renal vein. It drains into the hemiazygos 
vein. So the occlusion of the left renal vein does not impede the blood flow in the left subcostal 
vein. Veins that commonly drain into the left renal vein (which in turn drains into the IVC) are: • Left inferior phrenic (diaphragmatic) vein, • Left suprarenal (adrenal) vein, • Left gonadal vein On the right side, all the above veins drain into the inferior vena cava directly. 962 
Sold by @itachibot Apart from the veins described above, the first and second left lumbar veins and hemiazygos vein 
may drain into the left renal vein.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following structures does not cross the midline?
questions.explanation:
The left gonadal vein does not cross the midline. It is formed from the pampiniform plexus of 
veins and drains into the left renal vein. The left renal vein is longer than the right renal vein and it crosses the midline anterior to the 
aorta. It drains directly into the inferior vena cava. The right renal vein does not cross the midline. The accessory hemiazygous vein at T7 vertebral level crosses the midline to drain into the azygous 
vein. The root of the mesentery extends across a line from the duodenojejunal flexure on the left side to 
the sacroiliac joint on the right side. This spans a length of 15 cm and crosses the midline in its 
course.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 42-year-old man presented with severe pain in the lower back radiating to the pubic 
symphysis. Ultrasonography revealed a stone in the left ureter, measuring 3 mm in size. The 
stone is most likely to be lodged in which of the following sites?
questions.explanation:
Vesicoureteric junction is the narrowest part of the ureter. This is the reason why stones as small 
as 2 to 3 mm get arrested in the vesicoureteric junction. The ureter is constricted at 5 places: • Pelvi-ureteric junction • Brim of the lesser pelvis (as it crosses the common iliac artery) • Point of crossing of the ureter by ductus deferens or broad ligament of the uterus. • Vesico-ureteric junction 963 
Sold by @itachibot • Opening in the lateral angle of the trigone These are regarded as surgical constrictions of the ureter. However, only 1, 2, and 4 are the anatomical constrictions of the ureter.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following structure is not a posterior relation of the structure marked as X?
questions.explanation:
The structure marked in the image is the ureter. Quadratus lumborum is not a posterior relation 
of the ureter. Posterior relations of the ureter in the abdominal cavity are: • Psoas major • Genitofemoral nerve • End of the common iliac artery or beginning of the external iliac artery 964 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following arteries does not supply the ureters?
questions.explanation:
The superior mesenteric artery does not supply the ureters. The ureter receives its blood supply from the following arteries: • Renal artery • Gonadal artery • Common iliac artery • Internal iliac artery • Vesical artery • Uterine artery • Abdominal aorta Among these branches, the branch from the renal artery and the branch from the inferior vesical 
artery are always constant. Clinical note: The branch of the renal artery that supplies the ureter must be carefully preserved 
in renal transplantation to maintain good vascularity of the ureters.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following arteries does not supply the marked structure? 947 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The structure marked in the CT abdomen is the left adrenal gland. The superior mesenteric artery 
does not supply the suprarenal or adrenal gland. The adrenal gland receives its arterial supply from the superior, middle, and inferior suprarenal 
arteries. These arteries have some variations in their origin as follows: 965 
Sold by @itachibot Artery

questions.question: Question 20: Where does the right main adrenal vein drain into?
questions.explanation:
The right main adrenal vein usually drains into the inferior vena cava. 966 
Sold by @itachibot The left main adrenal vein usually drains into the left renal vein. Variations are common on the 
right side, where the right adrenal vein may drain into the right inferior phrenic vein.

questions.question:
Question 21: During the cystoscopic evaluation of a patient with hematuria, where will you find the 
Mercier's bar?

options.b: Between uvula vesicae and ureteric orifice
options.d: Between internal and external urethral orifice

questions.explanation:
The Mercier's bar (interureteric bar or interureteric ridge) is a curved fold of mucous membrane 
between the two ureteric orifices inside the bladder. This fold of mucous membrane is formed by the thickening of the superior border of the trigone 
muscle. In cystoscopy, the interureteric ridge appears as a pale band and acts as a guide to the 
ureteric orifices. The mucosal fold running from the uvula vesicae to the ureteric orifice is called the Bell's bar. This 
fold forms the lateral borders of the trigone. It contains a band of muscle fibres called the Bell's 
muscle. 967 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following lobes of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae?
questions.explanation:
The median lobe of the prostate forms the uvula vesicae. Uvula vesicae is an elevation in the mucous membrane of the urinary bladder, behind the internal 
urethral orifice. It is often enlarged in benign prostatic hypertrophy.

questions.question: Question 23: Where does the internal urethral orifice lie at birth?

options.a: At the level of the umblicus
options.b: At the level of the lower border of symphysis pubis
options.c: At the level of the perineal body
options.d: At the level of the upper border of symphysis pubis

questions.explanation:
The internal urethral orifice lies at the level of the upper border of the pubic symphysis at birth. At birth, the bladder is an abdominal organ. But as the child grows, the blader descends, and near 
puberty, it becomes a pelvic organ. In an adult, the internal urethral orifice lies 3–4 cm behind the lower part of the pubic symphysis. 
It corresponds to the bladder neck. Clinical note: As the bladder lies above the symphysis pubis, we can safely perform suprapubic 
needle punctures to obtain urine samples in children. But in adults, this can only be done if the 
bladder is fully distended.

questions.question: Question 24: Which of the following structures is innervated by the neurons present in Onuf's nucleus?
questions.explanation:
The external urethral sphincter is innervated by the neurons present in Onuf's nucleus. The neurons present in the lamina IX of the grey matter in spinal segments S2, S3, and S4 
constitute Onuf's nucleus. These neurons contract the external urethral sphincter. 968 
Sold by @itachibot The external urethral sphincter is made up of skeletal muscle fibers. In the contracted state, they 
are responsible for the maintenance of urinary continence. Just before the onset of voiding the 
sphincter is relaxed. This happens because the neurons in the Onuf's nucleus are centrally 
inhibited by the brain. The below image shows Onuf's nucleus located in the lamina IX. Nerve supply of the bladder: Parasympathetic supply 
Sympathetic supply From S2, S3, and S4 spinal s

Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 25: What is the number of arterial segments in the kidney?
questions.explanation:
There are five arterial segments in the kidney: • Apical • Superior • Middle • Inferior • Posterior Blood supply of the kidney: The renal artery is a direct lateral branch of the abdominal aorta. Near 
the hilum of the kidney, the renal artery is divided into anterior and posterior divisions. These 
divisions are further divided into five segmental arteries (four anterior and one posterior). The 
segmental arteries further branch out in a hierarchy to form different arteries. Finally, the renal 
vein is formed which joins the inferior vena cava. 970 
Sold by @itachibot 971 
Sold by @itachibot Internal and external genitalia
